awd_titl_txt: Standard Grant: Societal Aspects of Energy Infrastructure Expansion
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a research project that studies social aspects of efforts to expand the use of fracking for gas extraction, as well as corresponding efforts to expand gas processing and exportation, in the tri-state area constituted by Pennsylvania, New York, and New Jersey. The specific goal of this project is to better understand the role labor unions and their members play in the co-production of energy infrastructures. It will provide findings that will shed light on the social forces that shape energy infrastructures, and on how sociotechnical systems are developed, maintained, and how they can be changed. The PIs plan to publish peer reviewed articles in journals such as Science as Culture and Environmental Sociology, and to publish a book with MIT Press. To increase public understanding of energy expansions, the PIs will produce a white paper with the assistance of a design professional to create infographics for the white paper. They will also share key findings with labor unions and with key government offices including that of the Governor for each of the three states, and the Mayor and City Council of Philadelphia, New York City, and Trenton.

The proposed research project will examine efforts to expand gas infrastructure. It will combine STS literatures on energy systems with sociological research on organized labor, and it will multiple methods including content analysis, in-depth interviews, and fieldwork. It will investigate the technical and scientific expertise of key members of the different labor unions involved in the infrastructure development, and it will explore the extent to which that expertise impacts technology design and use, and the extent to which it is used in political debate and policy formation. The proposed research has the potential to bridge and to integrate the literatures in STS and sociology that is relevant to a fuller understanding of the role of labor and technology in environmental injustice; although there is some overlap between these literatures, they often are disconnected. Most researchers examining natural gas as an environmental justice issue focus on the extraction point of the energy supply chain, examining rural communities impacted by fracking. This project shifts the focus from communities near gas wells to the views and positions of groups at the transportation and refining points in the energy supply chain that are influential in either supporting or curtailing the conditions that bring about environmental injustice from fossil fuel energy technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the course of this project, we have examined how 10 national U.S. labor unions, and 101 labor union members and leaders in New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania, view the present and future of the U.S. energy system. The U.S. plays an outsized role in global energy politics, thus it is crucial to understand more about the societal aspects of our changing energy system, including the views and concerns of those who build and run the system. We gathered, coded and analyzed 1,396 files containing discourse on energy and work published by unions on union websites from 2012 to 2020 and conducted, coded and analyzed in-depth interviews lasting one hour with union members and leaders who work in energy industries, and lasting 30 minutes with union members and leaders who work in other industries.  A large proportion of the unions we studied represent people who work directly with energy technologies including natural gas infrastructures, and thus play a major role in making our energy system more just and environmentally sustainable. Our work builds upon the work of scholars who study transition management, environmental sociology, labor studies and science and technology studies, and integrates knowledge from these disparate academic literatures, increasing the knowledge base examining the social side of the sociotechnical energy system. Our work has shown that U.S. labor unions representing energy workers are at the forefront of energy transition politics: they are working to train the next generation of energy workers for work in new industries such as wind and solar power, while ensuring that a U.S. energy transition is enacted in a manner that is fair to energy workers in older industries such as coal and oil refining. In addition to academic publications, we have written two white papers based on our research and shared information with key government officials. The project has also advanced the training and skills base of a postdoctoral researcher and two undergraduate students
